section.title: Introduction
section.p: This document details the changes in the example configurations in and the impact these changes have on a fresh install of 3.0 as well as the implications for upgrade from .

Alternatively, you can also re-use your existing version 2 configurations for a fresh installation of - this will create a cloud based on the new 3.0 codebase, but missing new services that have been added and maintaining old services that have been either deprecated or removed. For more information on re-using version 2 configuration files with a fresh 3.0 installation, see the article Re-Using Existing Configuration Files in the installation section.
The structure of the example configurations provided in has changed as follows:

ul.li: entry-scale-kvm-vsa-mml has been promoted from "tech-preview" status.
mid-scale has been promoted from "tech-preview" status and renamed mid-scale-kvm-vsa.
entry-scale-esx has been replaced by the hybrid model entry-scale-esx-kvm-vsa.

section.title: Octavia
section.p: The Octavia Load Balancing Provider requires a provider network to be set up and configured in the input model prior to installing Octavia. For information on how to install Octavia, see the article Configuring Load Balancer as a Service.
Two new service components have been added to the sevice-components list in control_plane.yml:

Configuration data objects for Octavia and Neutron networks have also been added to the examples.
See octavia/octavia_config.yml and neutron/neutron_config.yml.

If you are upgrading from and want to enable support for Octavia, you will need to add these components and configuration data objects to your Input Model and then follow the installation instructions for Configuring Load Balancer as a Service.
